Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Food Production, Ritual, and Community Organization at Ancient Hualcayan (Ancash, Peru)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Rebecca Bria of Vanderbilt University will collaborate with Peruvian colleagues to study how people constitute new communities following the decline of interregional religious and political networks. Previous scholarship has shown how, during periods of political decline and regeneration, people use ritual performance to establish new community affiliations. Economic studies have also shown how new food production regimes transform community interaction. Building on and expanding these studies, this research focuses attention on the poorly understood links between these ritual and economic practices in order to broaden our understanding of the complex conditions, materials, and processes through which communities are established and organized. In particular, it studies how ritual and food production changed during a pivotal process of social transformation in Andean prehistory, characterized by the demise of the widespread Chavín religion and political network during the Early Horizon (900-1 B.C.E.) and the rise of localized Recuay agro-pastoral communities in the Early Intermediate Period (1-600 C.E.). Archaeology, a discipline that examines the long-term changes in materials and practices of past human societies, is particularly well suited to study this process of community regeneration. Broadly, the study contributes new perspectives on food production and community formation by focusing less on economic adaptation and more on the religious values and political motivations through which people shaped their environment and built a community. The project will also contribute insights to an important topic in anthropological research and contemporary politics: how people undergoing extensive political and religious change establish new social identities and define new kinds of community. The research has the potential to uncrease understanding of political changes which are occurring in many regions of the world today.

Rebecca Bria and her collaborators will investigate how ancient communities gained political and economic autonomy and reorganized local social affiliations during periods of regional political decline, particularly by establishing new food production regimes and new types of ritual performances. The study will analyze food remains excavated from ritual contexts at Hualcayán, an archaeological site that was continuously occupied during the period of Chavín decline and Recuay emergence in Ancash, Peru. The project hypothesizes that a transfor¬mation in community organization was predicated upon changes in ritual and food production, which had previously supported elites engaged in ritual activities at Hualcayán's Chavín temple and then provided the foundation for a new Recuay community rooted in corporate group rituals and agricultural management. To test the hypothesis, the project will analyze and compare macrobotanical, phytolith and starch, and faunal remains from the Chavín temple and from Recuay ritual compounds and tombs that are spatially embedded into a system of agricultural terraces, as well as date these contexts by 14C means. This analysis will document the degree to which people at Hualcayán transformed their Chavín temple site into a Recuay community by intensifying, diversifying, and ritualizing food production and will examine whether and how newly formed Recuay corporate groups were distinguished by ritual food preparation and consumption practices. The research will strengthen intellectual and cultural ties between Peru and the United States through an international scientific collaboration, and the results will be presented to the public in peer-reviewed publications and museum installations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of the research was to document the changing practices of food production and ritual consumption at the archaeological site of Hualcayán (highland Ancash, Peru) and identify their role in the social transformation of this ancient community during a pivotal moment in Andean prehistory: the demise of the widespread Chavín religion and political network during the Early Horizon (900-1 B.C.E.) and the rise of Recuay agricultural/agro-pastoral communities during the Early Intermediate Period (1-600 C.E.). To examine these community practices at Hualcayán, the project dated and analyzed botanical and faunal food remains, primarily from excavated ritual contexts.

Although a variety of research projects have examined Chavín and Recuay communities, the process through which the people of Ancash reconstituted themselves as Recuay communities after Chavín remains poorly understood. Existing research had revealed that during the Early Horizon, the Chavín network spread throughout the Central Andes, creating an unprecedented system of temple-based communities that were dominated by religious elites and centered on large mounds and plazas. These temple complexes were largely stages for public ceremonies during which elites expressed their central religious roles and esoteric knowledge by displaying exotic goods and orchestrating feasts. During the Early Intermediate Period, the Recuay began burying their dead in collective, often monumental tombs, intensified their feasting activities, and incorporated stone and ceramic effigies of local elites and ancestors into their feasts, which suggests the formation of different lineage-like corporate group identities within Recuay communities. They also built extensive agricultural terraces and corrals, features which have not been widely identified for the earlier Chavín period of the study area.

The analyzed food and radiocarbon data suggest that Hualcayán’s Chavín-era ritual economy—or the economic practices and materials produced for and used in ritual contexts—focused on the acquisition and consumption of foreign goods, such as mollusks traded from the Pacific Ocean. This ritual consumption also centered on a limited range of local agricultural products, primarily maize and potatoes, used in fairly standardized ways, perhaps stewed or fermented. In contrast, the data suggest that Recuay-era rituals were focused on the consumption of a wide diversity of local agricultural products—including maize, potato, sweet potato, peanut, bean, walnut, and quinoa—which were prepared and consumed in combination during feasts. Camelids and guinea pigs were also consumed in both Chavín and Recuay contexts, but in lower numbers than in published reports from other sites, suggesting that agriculture, rather than agro-pastoralism, was the central economic practice at Hualcayán.

These data support several broader findings about the ancient Hualcayán community when combined with the architectural evidence from Hualcayán. In particular, the research documented a decentralization of ritual activities after Chavín, as rituals shifted away from a ceremonial mound and into a series of dispersed ritual-agricultural compounds (open plazas/patios surrounded by food storage areas) that were located in terraced fields. Together, the food and architectural evidence suggests that while the Chavín ritual economy was focused on the production and consumption of foods according to liturgical guidelines and in support of centralized, hierarchical rituals, the Recuay ritual economy was focused on generating, celebrating, and performing the prosperity of one’s group, which was realized and symbolized through the production of a greater diversity of foods (i.e. risk reduction) and their storage and ritual consumption in separate compounds. In short, the people of Hualcayán forged a new Recuay community when they intertwined their lineage rituals with agricultural labor activities, and in so doing, created a ritual economy of food production that became the principal mechanism for local social organization.

The research contributes to anthropological theory in several ways. First, it contributes to theories that define communities as dynamic social entities that are constituted and transformed through changes in patterned social interactions—particularly the coordinated practices of ritual and food production. Second, it contributes to the literature on ritual economy and ecology by exploring agriculture as a ritual system. Third, it offers insights into how ritual food preferences can distinguish social positions and groups within a single community. Fourth, it is the first study to extensively analyze botanical remains from a Recuay site. Finally, the project fostered an intellectual and scientific exchange between Peruvian and American researchers. 

The project’s botanical and faunal analyses were performed in collaboration with Peruvian specialists at the ArqueoBios research laboratory in Trujillo, Peru (June–October 2015), where a variety of Peruvian students gained practical training. Radiocarbon dating of samples was performed by Direct AMS in Bothell, WA (October 2015–May 2016). The results are being disseminated as part of an ongoing outreach project in Peru by the Proyecto de Investigación Arqueológico Regional Ancash (PIARA), including a series of museum exhibitions and lectures to local municipalities and educational institutions. The project’s conclusions will be presented in the co-PI’s dissertation, synthesized on the PIARA webpage, and translated into Spanish for public dissemination.
